msDesc.head: Medical recipes and charms for horses

summary.seg: While most remedy collections that survive from the late Middle Ages provide ailments for human conditions (for instance, Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 9308), a small but significant number focused on cures for horses, reflecting the importance of these animals at the time. This manuscript is a composite of several texts largely made up of remedies intended for horses but with a small number of cures for human illnesses and other procedures in the later sections. Contemporary horse-care (or hippiatric) treatises – such as the famous On Medicines for Horses by Jordanus Ruffus – often included advice for horse owners on breeding, stabling, and training horses, however, this collection exclusively contains remedies and other materials relating to illnesses or adverse conditions. This likely reflects that it was intended for horse-doctors rather than stablemasters. This manuscript was principally written in Middle English with some French and Latin mainly in the names of conditions and in the charms and prayers.

The first and largest component of this manuscript is a section of the relatively common Boke of Marchalsi, a fifteenth-century horse-medicine treatise in Middle English (other examples include London, Wellcome Library, MS 5650, ff. 1r-28v). 'Marshalsi' was the practice associated with 'marshals', a professional class that arose in the later Middle Ages and provided prophylactic and interventionary veterinary care as well as shoeing horses. The Boke of Marchalsi was set out as a conversation between a master and their apprentice. This structure provided the author with opportunities to explain particular points of pharmacy and medicine as they relate to horse-care such as explaining why a disease is more likely to afflict one side of a horse's face than the other (f. 2r) or to explain and justify particular remedies that at first glance seem contradictory (e.g. 'Master, why should you give the horse either vinegar or milk, given that one is sour and the other sweet?': f. 11r). The first component of this manuscript follows a rough head-to-hoof organisation mirroring the head-to-toe schema that was common in contemporary remedy collections.

The rest of the manuscript is made up of several shorter collections of remedies mainly intended for horses, and contains cures attributed to several named marshals including William, marshal of Merton Priory in Surrey, Piers 'the Moor', and 'Hew Saracyn of Spayne' (f. 19r). Horses were an important international commodity in late-medieval England, and many were imported from Spain for royal and seigneurial stables. It was also not unusual for stablemasters from France and Spain to be employed by English aristocrats, so it is quite possible that Piers and Hew lived and worked in England or that their knowledge and practices were transmitted along international trade routes. Although this manuscript makes no direct reference to contemporary European horse-medicine writers, it does refer to the 'great marshals' and a disease which they called 'pynconeys' (f. 23v). This is likely a rendering of 'malum pinsanese', a condition found in the Latin works of Jordanus Ruffus, Laurentius Rusius and other influential late-medieval writers of horse-medicine treatises and so suggests that the authors of this manuscript were familiar with the wider world of veterinary medicine.

This collection includes remedies targeting a range of conditions: notably contagious diseases such as glanders (f. 3r) and farcy (ff. 5v-8v), wounds and bleeding (ff. 18v and 22v), and diseases of the eye (ff. 2r-2v, 18r), the face (f. 12v), mouth and tongue (ff. 3v-5r). There is a particular focus on injuries and conditions of the feet and legs (ff. 11v-14r, 19r-19v, 22v) reflecting how vulnerable a horse was to these sorts of ailments during its working life. This manuscript also contains remedies which reflect the working demands placed on horses, for instance procedures which corrected errors in a horse's gait (ff. 24r-24v) or issues with a horse's behaviour (ff. 22r, 25r). There are also procedures which aided a marshal or horse-keeper in their work, for instance advice on judging a horse's virtues (f. 11v), methods for making vinegar for medicines (ff. 14v-15r), and charms to make a horse stand still whilst it is being cared for or shod (ff. 25v-26r).

As well as veterinary procedures, the latter parts of this manuscript also include remedies for human ailments, reflecting the fact that veterinary and medical healing practices were not strictly separated in this period. These medical remedies offer cures for a range of ailments such as sciatica (f. 33v), toothache (ff. 34r, 37r), migraine (f. 34v), and childbirth (f. 35v). There are also non-medical instructions, such as an apotropaic procedure to protect a house from fire that involves placing a written talisman high up in the rafters of the building (f. 35v). The breadth of remedies and rituals found in this manuscript is a relatively common feature of late-medieval remedy collections which tended to attract an admixture of additional procedures, reflecting the needs or interests of the collections' writers and owners.

The veterinary procedures in this collection range from pharmacy, blood-letting and surgical interventions to rituals involving charms, prayers, and talismans. This is again reflective of the breadth of healing techniques employed in the late Middle Ages, in which magical and religious healing were equally valued alongside medical or surgical practices. This manuscript includes a particularly interesting set of veterinary rituals, which are indicated for a variety of conditions, notably a group of diseases referred to as farcy, glanders, or more generally 'the worm'. These were dangerous and highly contagious illnesses which could decimate a herd and as such were particularly feared by medieval horse-doctors and stablemasters. The rituals and charms in this manuscript range in complexity from a few simple words or a short prayer to procedures with multiple stages, prayers, magical incantations, and written talismans. Charms and prayers often invoked saints and Biblical figures or narratives that were perceived as having a particular relevance to the disease or condition under treatment. For instance, there are ritual remedies against farcy or the worm which use the figure of St Job (ff. 26v, 31r) who was assaulted by worms as part of his trials, and charms against bleeding which invoke the figure of Longinus, the centurion who according to legend pierced Jesus's side with a lance at the crucifixion (ff. 26r-26v, 32r).

This manuscript also features a set of unusual rituals that were intended to aid a horse afflicted by farcy, which involved preparing a talisman or magical object and then attaching it to the horse with sutures. In one ritual the reader is instructed to write magical words and symbols on a lead token and place it under the skin of the horse's forehead (f. 35r). In another, the object is made from the roots of red nettle and red dock twisted together into a cross and tied to crosses made of leather and lead. These three crosses were perhaps intended to reflect the Trinity or the three crosses at Calvary. The reader is then instructed to stitch this object to their horse, 'just as Christ joined His precious body to the cross' (f. 6r). This type of procedure appears to be peculiar to remedies against contagious diseases in horses (for other examples, see, London, Wellcome Library, MS 5650, ff. 14v-16r and London, British Library, MS Harley 6398, ff. 28v –29v). Like many charms and magical healing rituals from this period, it relied on the performer creating an analogical relationship between the patient (in this case a horse) and a powerful Biblical narrative of redemption and resurrection.

Dr Sunny Harrison
Associate Lecturer
Open University

msContents.textLang: Middle English, Latin, and Middle French

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes and charms for the treatment of ailments in horses, the second part of The Boke of Marchalsie
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes, ending with two lines in Middle French
msItem.rubric: 1r Here bygynneþ þe maladies þat hors haueþ of her own kynde
msItem.incipit: 1r There hors beþ norisched in her [ȝowþe] wiþ hard mete and benes or barly or hard corailes wiþ suche mete whenne he etiþ wiþ grete wille so wexeþ þe humour of þe hed to muchel and grete undir þe iȝen and þat makiþ þe iȝen to water and after þat comeþ a goute al ouer þe iȝen
msItem.explicit: 18v A plastre to don awey wickide fleish. Take þe white of an ey and quik sond and tempere hit to gedre til þat hit be þicke Seynt archedelyn en son haut se vij. verge de rounce tyent en sa mayn sy il beyt quit purson chynal [sic] et sors estoyt
msItem.note: The collection contains an elaborate charm-ritual for curing farcy (ff. 5v-7r), and a charm to staunch blood (f. 18r)

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 9.
Hindley (2023), p. 194 [transcription and translation of charm to staunch blood]

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 18v ffor swellyng þe necke take barly and seþ yt wel and yeue yt þe hors to etyn and none oþer prouender
msItem.explicit: 18v ffor þe strangloun Take garlyc
msItem.note: Added in the 15th century.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 9.

msItem.title: Collection of charms and a recipe for healing diseases of horses
msItem.textLang: Middle English with a Latin rubric
msItem.rubric: 19r Practica Willelmi Marescalli Prioris Mertone de infirmitate equorum
msItem.incipit: 19r Crist hym self was y bore in bemergebyre in benynbyre. Bedleem hit hiȝt
msItem.explicit: 19r þis hors be delyuered of wormes. botes. and schurf of skyn. by þe offryng of þes candells in þe worship of seint ffirmyn
msItem.note: The collection begins with a charm to staunch blood and ends with a charm to cure farcy that invokes St Fermin and is attributed to Hew sarasyn of spayne.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 9.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes and charms for curing horses
msItem.rubric: 19r þis is þe marchalcie of Piers Moriz good and trewe
msItem.incipit: 19r Thus seiþ Piers þe moriz. þat ȝif hit so be ȝat an hors come to hym to be marchelid at ȝe first he drawiȝ of his schoon forto seche ȝe foot
msItem.explicit: 27v ffor the peynes Bynde ther grece of a bore and aftirward boile benes and ffry hem in shepes talow with salt garlik and arment and lay to the sore and he shall be hole
msItem.note: The collection contains a charm for curing farcy in a horse and for shoeing a horse that invokes St Eligius on f. 25v; and another charm for curing farcy that invokes St Job on f. 26v.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes for treating horses
msItem.incipit: 23r ffor þe strangloun take þe garlyc and stampe yt and tempere yt with þe Jus of syngrene and boyle yt with swyne ys grece in a litel ale and geue yt þe hors to drycnke at hote as he may souery
msItem.explicit: 23r ffor þe stone take pappewort and benet and bappetarde and schaue hem and seþe hem in white wyn and take þe jus of morelle and of celedoyne and as moche
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by the same 15th-century hand that added recipes to f. 18v; here, the first recipe continues the third recipe on f. 18v.

msItem.title: Charm for an unspecified purpose
msItem.incipit: 23r maguba magula mala et ?Jop magula et Pater noster et ave maria
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for curing a short-winded horse
msItem.rubric: 23r ffor an hors þat ys pursyf
msItem.incipit: 23r Take an holde dogge of þe same here þat þyn hors hys and seþ hym here and alle excepte þe guttes and bray hym small in a morter bonys and alle and streyne hem þerwe a cloth wiþ ys same lycour and let hyt stonde
msItem.explicit: 23r Affter þys tyddynge wolwynge a drenche þat ys to sayng i unce of greynys a i unce of gynger camphur i unce clouis ij unces dragates [ounces] i anixden succ j licorices and [ouncs] i candall all and rubij and citrium
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm for horseshoeing
msItem.rubric: 25v for to make a hors to stonde still while he ys shoy[?g]
msItem.incipit: 25v Benedicite dominus + Nos a deo qui [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription attempted. Partly illegible because the text has faded or has been erased; added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm for horseshoeing invoking St Eligius
msItem.incipit: 26r In nomine patris et filii etcaetera The same charme þat Seynt Loyd hadde Whan þat he fyrst hors chode Seynt loy
msItem.explicit: 26r Also ycharme the by þe same charme þat þou abit to me as þou abit to Seynt loy in þe worchip of þe v woundes þat god Souffret þe goode fryday Istat etcaetera In nomine Patri et fillii
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Two charms for curing an unspecified ailment
msItem.incipit: 27r Ma tha be o s [...] / Tetragrammaton: prykke the oneres and say the nethes
msItem.explicit: 27r Bure. Burere. Bue . Rere. and in the worschip of god and of oure lady seint Marie and seint John the Baptist and for his fadur soule and his modur soule p[o]ur cherite Pater noster iij tymes with iij Aves thries ysaid
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by the same 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Two charms for curing the farcy
msItem.incipit: 27v A charme for þe fassion +++ Propretia deus destruet de in finem
msItem.explicit: 27v et si fuerit equa ponatur in auricula senystra
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm to staunch blood
msItem.rubric: 28r ffor to stanche blod
msItem.explicit: 28r In nomine patris filij et spiritus sancti Amen + Sicud vere credimus quod sancta maria vere genitt [sic] Christum tu vena reine tuum sanquinem
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm for curing the farcy
msItem.rubric: 28r A medycyne for þe farsyoun
msItem.incipit: 28r Sey thus Jhesus wente to bethelem mette he with Seynt John þe ewangelist whi ledest þow þy fole yn þy hand seyde Jhesus to seynt John the Ewangelist lord for he hath þe ffassye and may not go
msItem.explicit: 28r and he shal neuer haue þe ffassyne no non hors þat stant by hym seyde Jhesus to seynt John þe ewangelist by ix dayes to gedere
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm for curing the farcy that invokes St Nicasius
msItem.rubric: 28v A charme for þe fassine In þe name of þe fader + and of þe sone + and þe holy gost + Amen + Seynt Nicase hadde a lidore euel + And he prayde to god + that who so euer bere his name vp on hym + of þis yvel he shal be delyuered
msItem.explicit: 28v And let hit be bounde in þe right ere of an hors in þe saturday afore sonne goynge downe And lat hit a byde still tille þe Mounday afore sonne risynge and þanne take hit out and he shal be hole. And if a mere haue þis grevaunce put þis charme in to here lift ere in þe same maner forsayd
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm for curing the farcy that invokes St Nicasius
msItem.incipit: 28v + In nomine patris + et filij + et spiritus sancti. + amen + sanctus Nigasius habuit minutam bestiolam que vexabatur morbo ffarciaco
msItem.explicit: 28v Sanctus Nigasius oret pro te Soror + Opheas + Cleophas + Neophas + Phendula + Gendula + dracones sunt + In nomine domini mortuus est vermis + Amen + In nomine patris + filij + et spirits sancti + amen + a + g + l + a + + + e + o + r + a + g + r + a + m + a + t + o + u + Amen +++++
msItem.note: Added by a late 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Sage leaf charm for curing fever
msItem.rubric: 29r A medicyn ffor þe Axes
msItem.incipit: 29r Take a sawge lef þat is not perced and write þer on with a penne with ynke in principio principio erat verboum angelus nunciat
msItem.explicit: 29r And seye þe prayers forseyde and þe þridde day take anoþer lef and write þer on Et deus erat verbum Cristus tonat and ȝif hit þe seke a[nd] let hym seye þe prayers forseyde And by goddis grace he shal be hole
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 11.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating haemorrhoids
msItem.rubric: 29r ffor þe emerawdes
msItem.incipit: 29r Take lek þat neuer was set: but as hit was sowe oþer ellis take lek þat was set afore mydsomer
msItem.explicit: 29r ad make a plaster þerof and ley þe plaster vpon a clout of scarlet and as hot as ȝe may ley hit to ȝowre foundement and þis is proued
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that added the charms to f. 27r.

msItem.title: Recipe for making dye
msItem.incipit: 29r Take a pynte of paynters oyle and an ounce of red led an ounce of mastik and an ounce of ȝelow oker and a bene gretnesse of frankencense as muche of spaynyssh grene as much of coperose put hem in to a pot and sethe hem tille hit reme as brid by [.]ne
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Six recipes for dyeing cloth
msItem.rubric: 29v A gode medysyn for þe Glaundres
msItem.incipit: 29v ffor to make whit cloth of damaske: Take newe whit cloith þer to beþe a penyworth of blanke plumme and grynde hit on a stoun
msItem.explicit: 29v ȝif ȝowre cloith be red ȝowre damaske moste be sadder red and ȝif hit be blew hit moste be lighter blew etcaetera
msItem.note: Added by a single 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes and charms
msItem.incipit: 31r ffor pursie of an hors: Make an hors faste iij dayes and iij nyght and take an olde mastif dogge and sede hym wel in water and ȝif the hors to drynke as hot as he may suffre
msItem.explicit: 31v and take out þe pythe with ynne and let sethe hem yn a potell of whit wyn yn to a quart and vse þis al euen and at morwe with as muche suger as wol make hit lusty to ȝowre taste and anoynte ȝow with oynement taghte byfore
msItem.note: Added by a single 15th-century hand; includes two charms for curing farcy, one against worms, one for curing al maner [of] yveles, and one for treating glanders in horses, invoking Job and St Hippolytus.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 12-13.

msItem.title: Charm to staunch blood
msItem.incipit: 32r Longens Miles Ebreus lancia [added in a different hand: \Christi/] latus perforauit
msItem.explicit: 31v Credimus quod sancta maria est mater dei: et verum Infantem genuit Jhesum Christum sic resistant tue vene que [added in a different hand: sunt] sangguine plene [added: vt ab eis non exeat sanguis per virtutem eiusdem patris et filij et spiritus sancti amen]
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.rubric: 32r Thys is ffor the vivis
msItem.incipit: 32r Take hounddis tungge ij honde ffull or iij and pound hem in a morter till thou haue iij sponfull and pitte hit half in the oene ere
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand. Imperfect due to the removal of the lower half of the leaf.

msItem.title: Excerpts from liturgical texts
msItem.incipit: 32v Suscipias dominus sacrificium de manibus tuie [sic: tuis] at laudem et
msItem.explicit: 32v ffuit homo missus a deo
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand; similar inscriptions on f. 32r (fragmentary) and f. 37r.

msItem.title: Prayer-charm for curing farcy
msItem.incipit: 33r God and synt Copelyn swych grase as god ȝaf þe send from þe to me for þese bestys botye to be amen for charite in nomine patris et fili
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand, but later crossed out. Another copy of this text features on the lower half of the same page but by a different hand.

msItem.title: Magical formulae
msItem.incipit: 33r + zaron + zer[o]nen + zeronem + betonen + astra + lubia +
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand; two other copies of this charm occur on f. 35r.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.rubric: 33r for þe Eretica
msItem.incipit: 33r Take hony and oyle olyf and ueneger and white salt smale ygrounde euene euene porciouns
msItem.explicit: 33r And boyle hem til þey be brownne and ley hit to þe maledy with blak wolle
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm for horseshoeing
msItem.rubric: 33r ffor to make a hors to stond still while he is shchod
msItem.incipit: 33r Benedicit dominus + Nos a deo qui sumus sumpturi Benedicat dextera Christi In Nomine patris et filij et spiritus sancti Amen
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by the same 15th-century hand that copied the next two items; another copy of the text was added by a different hand to f. 25v.

msItem.title: Prayer-charm for curing farcy
msItem.rubric: 33r A prayar ffor þe ffasciun to be seyde with gode deuociun
msItem.incipit: 33r God and Synt Copelyn swych grase as god ȝaff þe send ffro þe to me ffor þese bestis bote bote to be amen for charite in nomine patris et ffilij et spiritus sancti amen
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by the 15th-century hand that copied the previous and next items; another copy of this text features at the top of the page (crossed out), but by a different hand.

msItem.title: Latin charm with Middle English heading
msItem.rubric: 33r A charme for þe trenches
msItem.incipit: 33r + vrinem + burnem + baburnen + basion + tetragramaton + repp. +
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by the same 15th-century hand that copied the preceding two items; later crossed out.

msItem.title: Collection of nine medical recipes and charms
msItem.incipit: 33v þis potage wull kepe a man lascatyfe: Take þe leuis of smalache or þe þe Rote venell water cerssis mercuri cliþeryn of eche liche moche and make wortes and put þerto oyle or schepis talowe and salte
msItem.explicit: 34r As þou mayste strayne hem þorow a cloþe and put hit ynto a clene vessell and þis medycyn haþ ben prouyd
msItem.note: Added by a single 15th-century hand; the collection includes a Latin charm for the toothache that invokes Doubting Thomas.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for curing a head ailment (perhaps headache)
msItem.incipit: 34v Take the rotys of the pryme rosyne and stanpe hem smalle and temper hame to gederys wyth the galle of a nox and anoynte the fore hede ther wyth
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for curing the eyes
msItem.rubric: 34v A powder for a hors yȝen good and treu
msItem.incipit: 34v Take the scyllys of hene eggys and brenne hem in a erthen potte and and [sic] mak poudyr þereoff and putte hyt in hys yȝy
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm against worms in a horse
msItem.rubric: 34v A charme for the wormys in an hors
msItem.incipit: 34v In nomine patris et filij et spiritus sancti amen pater noster aue Maria lord that sendist vertu in Stone in Worde in Grasse Sende Vertu in my vorde
msItem.explicit: 34v Sey thys ffyrst atte nekke then atte mydde side and then atte crowpe wyth iij tornys j atte eueri time With a pater noster aue maria atte eueri time bende a peny on the hors hede in the worshypp of seynte loij
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 15.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes for the eyes and gout
msItem.incipit: 34v for to clere a manys syȝt: take eufrasye iiij hanful and ij or red feenel and stylle yt and wasshe the yen therewith
msItem.explicit: 34v for the gowte: ipreuyd by seyn cutbert take mylle of one colowr and the jusse of merche and barleyme and boyle hit ryȝt welle togedere and al hote ley hit to þe sore
msItem.note: The second recipe is attributed to St Cuthbert. Added by the same late 15th- or early 16th-century hand that copied a recipe for the stomach on f. 38r.

msItem.title: Charm for horseshoeing
msItem.rubric: 35r Thes wordys scolde be wrete in lede and sette hyt in þe hors hod
msItem.incipit: 35r + zaron + zeronen + zeronem + batonent + astra + lubia
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by the same 15th-century hand that added the next item; other copies of this charm occur on f. 33r and f. 35r (lower half).

msItem.title: Medical recipe for purging the kidneys
msItem.rubric: 35r ffor the purgyng off a mannys raynys
msItem.incipit: 35r Take saxferage mylfoyle aneyse venelsede of euerych a nownce or ij and gromylle ysoppe hertistong maydyn here mowsere of euryche a quarter of an hondfulle The rotys of perseli
msItem.note: Full transcription of incomplete recipe: a complete version of this recipe can be found on f. 31v. Added by the same 15th-century hand that added the preceding item.

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.incipit: 35r Take the rotis of the primrosyin and stanpe hit in a morter and temper hit withe white wyne and take the juce therof and putte hitte in to his nose and hold hit ther tille he fele hit in the rofe of his mowthe and he sachall [sic: schall] be sauide
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm for curing or protecting a horse
msItem.rubric: 35r Thes wordys scold be wrte in lede and sette hit in the hors hed
msItem.incipit: 35r + zaron + zeronen + zeronem + betonent + astra + lubia
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand, which also copied the charm on f. 35r (upper half). A different hand copied the charm on f. 33r.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for curing sciatica
msItem.incipit: 35v Tak the rotys of the rede netel and the rote of the wyldenepe and wylde sauge and herbente and oyle oleue and maybotter and grued hem al togedere and do ther to a penewort of mastyk for the syatyk
msItem.note: Full transcription. Identical to the next item, but added by a different 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for curing sciatica
msItem.rubric: 35v ffor the sciatica
msItem.incipit: 35v Take the rotis of the rede nettil and the rote of wylde nepe and wylde sauge and herbe bennet oyle olife and mary butter grynd them smale together qand do therto a pennye worth of masticke
msItem.note: Full transcription. Identical to the previous item, but added by two different 15th-century hands.

msItem.title: Medical recipe to strenghten women after childbirth
msItem.rubric: 35v To strenghten a woman after her childbirthe
msItem.incipit: 35v Take v leuide gras and take nepe and a litile milfoyle and poude hit samale [sic: smalle] wrynge owte [added: \the iowse/} and medille alle to gedir and dryke [sic: drynke] hit ffurste afftir thy deliueraunse of þe chylde in warme ale or vine vethyr ȝe wille vithe a litil maye butir warmyde
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by the same 15th-century hands that copied the previous item.

msItem.title: The epitaph of St Agatha (charm for protection against fire)
msItem.incipit: 35v Mentem sanctam spontaneam honorem deo et patrie liberacionem

note.p: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand; the final rubric seems to have been added in a different contemporary hand and Connolly (2009), p. 17, lists it as a separate item. Connolly identifies the rubric as the introductory heading for a medical charm that has gone missing with the lower section of the leaf, suggesting that it may have been intended for curing 'erysipelas' (wildfire). Not only is there no evidence that a text was ever written below the rubric, but the rubric also refers to a 'hous', not a 'hors' as Connolly transcribes it. It seems much more likely that the rubric refers to the preceding Latin inscription (cited above): this is the epitaph that, according to hagiographic sources such as the Legenda Aurea, was inscribed on a marble table that an angel placed at the tomb of St Agatha of Catania in Sicily. Subsequently, the cloth that covered her tomb stopped a great fire or eruption of Mount Etna that threatened the city of Catania. On this basis, she has historically been invoked for protection against fire, sometimes with or solely through the citation of her epitaph.

Evidence of this practice in late medieval England comes from a charm against fire that cites the epitaph on ff. 121v and 136v of 15th-century English manuscript London, British Library, Add MS 12195 (this manuscript is noted by J.G.N., 'Ancient Charm against Fire', The Gentleman's Magazine, 180 (1846), 383-384 (p. 383)).

msItem.title: Charm for curing toothache
msItem.incipit: 37r A charme for þe toth ache abraham lay in þe mounte of olyuet
msItem.explicit: 37r th[i]s schal be ysayde þre sydys wyth v pater noster and v aue knelyng
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe (title only)
msItem.incipit: 37r ffor ethyk and tysyk boile þe leues
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Liturgical formulae
msItem.incipit: 37r Soror mea hominis [...]
msItem.explicit: 37r ffuit homo missus a cui nomen erat
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand; similar to the formulae on f. 32v.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for curing throat ailments
msItem.rubric: 37r for the garget probat
msItem.incipit: 37r Garget wort, hartes horne, Rewe pugil., \[...] chopped smale/ boyle them in a quarte of stronge ale and geve to drinke. my Aunt Greene
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a late 16th-century hand, perhaps that of Thomas Peapes, who inscribed his name in the outer margin of f. 6v.

msItem.title: Six medical recipes for curing different ailments
msItem.incipit: 37v ffor the syatyka: tak ij hanful of wormode and j hanfol of reue and a quart of rede wyne and a quart of oyle oleve and pyt hym in a pot of newe
msItem.explicit: 38r for a felon broune wert lef and ley þerto and sle hym for a felon
msItem.note: Added by a single 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe to ease the stomach
msItem.rubric: 38r forto defye a mannys stomake
msItem.incipit: 38rTake and by a penyworth of valsyn elys and seþe hem yn sauyre sausse and ȝete hym bonys and all and hyt most be vsyd iij dayes togeder and an warrantyse he shal be mery yn his hert and lyȝt yn hys body body [sic] probatum est
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by the same late 15th- or early 16th-century hand that added the recipes for sight and gout on f. 34v.

msItem.title: Prose treatise on the virtues of rosemary
msItem.rubric: 38v Here bethe vertuis of þe rosemarey
msItem.incipit: 38v Take þe flouris and bray hem a litill and bynd and sethe hem in vater in hal wyndell and yif þe sek to drink and þat is gode for al maner euellis
msItem.explicit: 39r also mak puder of þe leues and ette þerof and drink þerof wiþ whit vine and it woll ipourch þe seke stomak
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that added the next text.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 17-18.

msItem.title: Prose treatise on the virtues of betony
msItem.rubric: 38v Here bethe vertuis of betoyn
msItem.incipit: 39r betoyn ettyn or drynkkyn it wolle brekyn þe ston and mak þe seke pisse
msItem.explicit: 39r betoyn is grassius and foll of vertew and wo so hath aney [else] or aney othyr ffantissy henge þerof about is nekke [and it s]hall go way
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that added the previous text.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 18.

msItem.title: Collection of thirteen recipes and charms
msItem.incipit: 39v Ad faciendum nerwalt accipe wylsaygh camamelle boteyn verwyn sauge myntyn sowe herynwod modyrwort warmot water crassyn maluus cheken met sropes of netellis lorelle lewys walwort planteyn rybwort muser pympernoll tannessey herbe robart anens milfoylle peti consent dicaundy egremon and þe wirt of orpyn
msItem.explicit: 40r for to scle wormus þat is in a hors tak i potell of se coun alle and as moch alym as ahen ney and melt it and do þerto a porcioun of argollment and seth hem to geder and yf it þe seke to drinke al cold iij dayes
msItem.note: The collection contains a charm against parasites in a horse (ffor to charm a hors of virsaunt).
Added by a single 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: A short medical recipe
msItem.rubric: 40r This is for a stubbyng
msItem.incipit: 40r Oile balsam, Mercurye, Elisaunder, ffrankencens, Vynegre, þis is for þe stubbyng
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Charm against worms in a horse
msItem.rubric: 40r ffor þe trenchis a charme
msItem.incipit: 40r + vrnem + burnem + basion + Tetragramaton + Jepp. + [pentagram]
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by the same 15th-century hand that added the next charm.

msItem.title: Abacadabra charm for curing fever
msItem.rubric: 40r þis a charme for þe accesse
msItem.incipit: 40r Abracalans
msItem.explicit: 40r Ab
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that added the previous charm.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for dropsy (fragment)
msItem.rubric: 40v for the dropesy
msItem.incipit: 40v Tak mathagon and grynde hym in ale and dreng hem in ale fast yn ?etcaetera
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand and repeated twice: the third version read here because the first version is crossed out and unfinished and the second version is partly cut off (however it was originally complete, ending slightly differently from the third version: 'in ale ferst and last').

msItem.incipit: 40v+ aabcdeffghijklmnopq
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th-century hand.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
Folio numbers 16, 17, 30, 36 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library).

p.formula: 18 28-1 (8th leaf excised, probably blank) 38-1 (1st leaf excised, probably blank) 48-1 (6th leaf not present) 58-1 (4th leaf not present)

supportDesc.condition: Stains on pages, occassionally damaging the text. The final two quires are of thinner parchment with leaves that have become much cockled.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Single columns. 34 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The manuscript's original texts are written by a single hand in a cursive Anglicana script.
The manuscript's added texts are written by various hands in cursive scripts predominantly with Anglicana andSecretary features.

decoNote.p: Two- and one-line plain initials in blue or red.
Titles of recipes have been rubricated in red ink throughout.
Crosses in charms in blue or red ink.

note.p: 'fefty six pound I hath': incomplete marginal note on a payment, added by a hand of the 16th- or 17th-century (f. 1r).
'the farcyne': marginal annotation by a 17th-century hand, relating to a recipe (f. 7v).
'as much sparow gras as came to two ?sh ?peg 4d and 10: incomplete marginal note on a payment added by a hand of the 17th-century (f. 15r).
'Cresnor + Crespe': a formula, perhaps a charm, perhaps added by a hand of the 16th-century (f. 15v).
'Elizabeth ?regina anglie ff': crossed out inscription, added by a hand of the second half of the 16th century (f. 18v).
Collation formula by the hand of H.L. Pink, c. 1958 (inside lower cover).

binding.p: Binding by Gray of Cambridge, dated 1965 by a note on the front pastedown. Millboard three-quarter binding with marbled cloth covering and brown leather spine.
Binding height: 245 mm, width: 170 mm, depth: 20 mm.
The manuscript was previously bound together with Cambridge, University Library, MSS Dd.4.43, Dd.4.45, and Dd.4.46

origin.p: The original part of the manuscript was copied in the first quarter of the 15th century, but various additions were made throughout the 15th century (including a few 16th-century additions).

provenance.p: Thomas HobwoodThomas Hobwood: his unfinished ownership inscription in a 16th-century script on f. 1r: 'Thomas Hobwood hys'.
Thomas PeapesThomas Peapes: his name inscribed in a 16th-century script in the left margin of 6v: 'by me Thomas Peapes'.
John LaneJohn Lane: his name inscribed in a 17th- or 18th-century hand in the upper margin of 1v with the possible date '1765' inscribed in the upper margin of f. 2r.

John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : Dd.4.45 (with which Dd.4.43, Dd.4.45, and Dd.4.46 were bound together) is no. 606 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

acquisition.p: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on inside upper corner of CUL MS Dd.4.43, with which it as previously bound.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74); and Margarget Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), The Index of Middle English Prose (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009).
